bibl.title: Despatch from Charles H. J. Taylor to James D. Porter, July 2, 1887
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: Chas. H. J. Taylor to Hon. Jas. D. Porter
Attention to Postage acc't for 2nd quarter ending June 30th 1887
No. 7. U.S. Consulate Monrovia Liberia July 2nd 1887
Hon. Jas. D. Porter Assistant Sec. of State Washington D. C.

Sir: I have the honor to call your attention to my despatch No 5 dated June 30th 1887, and to the enclosure of said despatch No 5 in reference to contingent Expense for 2nd quarter, in said reports returned the Postage Act at $12.16. The Postmaster was in the country at the time, and upon his return, I am informed that instead of the legation (U.S.) owing $12.16 the qur't should be $15.58/100. I write this as an explanation

Please find enclosued the voucher from Postmaster for said amn't, which I have this day paid, by draft on the Hon. Sec of State for said amn't and charged the same to the contingant allowance for the 2nd quarter. I hope that from now on, the business of this legation may be conducted in such a way as to gain the approval of the Department with great consideration. I am your ob't servant
Chas H. J. Taylor U.S. Consul General

P.S. It must be remembered, that Mr. S.S. Sevier setted all the expenses of the second quarter, saving the "Postage bill," and is therefore responsible. The making of the report of course devolved on me.
